citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The attending veterinarian was not consulted on June 19, 2024, regarding an adult male ferret (ID 900263000108037),
after his health continued to decline following the initial treatment recommendations. Instead, when the attending
veterinarian could not be reached, an employee euthanized the ferret without a veterinarian consultation. According to the
program of veterinary care, all euthanasia will be performed by the veterinarian. When the attending veterinarian is not
given the appropriate authority, the provision of veterinary care may be inadequate or inappropriate. The licensee must
assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to
oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.
Corrected by: August 30, 2024.

This facility has developed a contingency plan, however, employees hired since the last inspection (over 30 days ago),
have not been trained on the plan, per facility representatives. It is important that employees are trained on the
contingency plan so a proper response can occur in case of an emergency. Dealers, exhibitors, intermediate handlers,
and carriers must provide training for their personnel regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the plan.
Newly hired employees must be trained on the plan within 30 days of their start date. Any substantive changes to the plan
as a result of the annual review must be communicated to employees through training which must be conducted within 30
days of making the changes.
Correct by: September 30, 2024.

In the back right corner of Room 3, an indoor room housing ferrets, was a standing puddle of yellow fluid on the floor
which appeared to be urine. This triangular puddle was located under a bank of ferret enclosures at a lower spot in the
floor that encompassed the entire corner (from approximately 2 feet in length along each wall). A strong ammonia odor
was also present within this room. Per a facility representative, the floor gets swept once a day and wet
mopped/vacuumed once every 2-3 days. Waste accumulation can lead to odors that impact the health and well-being of
the ferrets as well as attract pests and create disease hazards. Provisions shall be made for more frequent removal and
disposal of animal wastes to both minimize odors and disease hazards.
Correct by August 30, 2024.

Upon entering two of the six indoor housing rooms of ferrets (Rooms 1 and 3), a strong odor of ammonia was detected.
These rooms have recently been remodeled with new air conditioning ducts installed and the previous exhaust fans
removed. The odor was easily detectable by the inspector even while wearing a face mask. The inspector experienced
some eye watering upon standing in each these two rooms. Excessive ammonia inhalation can be detrimental to animal’s
comfort and health especially affecting the respiratory system and irritating the eyes of those housed indoors. The
housing facilities must be sufficiently ventilated for the health and well-being of the animals by minimizing odors, drafts,
ammonia levels and moisture condensation.
Correct by: August 30, 2024.

Approximately 25 percent of the food receptacles used in each of the ferret rooms are in need of cleaning. There is either
a buildup of brownish black waxy material and/or dried food on the sides and edges of the affected bowls. Per a facility
representative, the food bowls are not on a routine cleaning schedule. The food bowls need to be cleaned to keep the
food placed therein wholesome, palatable and free from contamination. Food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary
at all times.
Correct by: September 1, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
